title: 112_hr3760
content: The Act titled "Collaborative Academic Research Efforts for Tourette Syndrome Act of 2011" amends the Public Health Service Act to expand, intensify, and coordinate activities related to Tourette Syndrome under the National Institutes of Health programs. The Secretary, through the Director of NIH, will expand and coordinate programs for Tourette syndrome. Data collection will include epidemiologic information on the incidence and prevalence of Tourette syndrome in the US, as well as related comorbid conditions. The data collection system will gather information on medical and social services for individuals with Tourette syndrome and their families, categorized by population and region. The Secretary will award grants for centers of excellence to conduct research on Tourette syndrome, focusing on its causes and treatments. Research on Tourette syndrome should focus on cause, diagnosis, early detection, prevention, control, and treatment. Centers of excellence will conduct research in developmental neurobiology, genetics, and psychopharmacology. Additionally, services for patients include raising awareness about research opportunities and providing referrals for health services. The text describes the criteria for awarding grants to centers conducting research on Tourette syndrome, including availability and access to clinical services. Centers can be single institutions or consortiums of cooperating institutions. The Secretary will establish 4-6 centers for research on Tourette syndrome, with eligibility requirements for institutions or groups to participate in a consortium. Geographical distribution of the centers will be determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish 4-6 research centers for Tourette syndrome in different regions of the United States, encouraging consortium formation across multiple states. Support for each center may last up to 5 years, with possible extensions for additional 5-year periods based on center operations. The Secretary will establish research centers for Tourette syndrome in the US, with support lasting up to 5 years and possible extensions based on peer review recommendations. Grants will be awarded for research on symptomology and treatment efficacy, funded from the NIH budget.
